Award.AwardTitle: Kokes Awards for the 25th North American Catalysis Society Meeting

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will support graduate and undergraduate participation in the 25th meeting of the North American Catalysis Society (NACS) to be held in Denver, Colorado June 4-9, 2017. Specifically, the funds will provide assistance to 30 students from U.S. universities for registration fees and travel related expenses as administered through the Kokes Travel Award program sponsored by the NACS. The students will present their research at the conference, attend lectures by leaders in the field of catalysis, and provide assistance to the organizers in running the meeting.

The biennial NACS meetings are the largest North American meetings dedicated to catalysis. Student participation helps train young researchers in this vital aspect of science and engineering that supports advances in environmental pollution control, energy utilization, sustainability, and greenhouse gas reduction, thereby building the next generation of catalytic scientists and engineers working to ensure competitiveness of our Nation's chemical and petroleum industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The biennial North American Catalysis Society (NACS) meeting is the premier conference in the area of catalysis, surface science and reaction engineering in the United States.  The 25th North American Meeting (NAM) had a theme of Mile High Catalysis, and was held the week of June 4-9, 2017 in Denver, CO at the Hyatt Regency Hotel.  Meeting objectives included bringing together leading researchers for intensive scientific exchange, providing students with an opportunity to present their work and interact with leaders in the field, and having students participate in service to scientific/technical community.  Student participation has always been encouraged throughout the history of the meeting and the 25th meeting was no exception.  As part of this meeting, a select number of students were chosen to receive the Richard J. Kokes Travel Award. Three hundred eighty-six completed applications were received, and included applications from undergraduate and graduate students at universities in U.S., Mexico and Canada. The awardees were chosen on merit-based guideline with an effort to include students from as many research groups as possible and to ensure appropriate representation from underrepresented groups, including minorities and women, first-time attendees, and students of young faculty.  The process included evaluation of the student’s CV, the letter of recommendation from the student’s adviser (and the ranking by the advisor if more than one student from that research group applied), and the abstract. All abstracts were peer-reviewed. Ninety-four students, Kokes awardees, were offered in kind a total of $886 to offset the cost of registration ($295, early registration fee) and funds for a shared hotel room ($591).  In addition, 4 Kokes award offers were made to local students; these offers only included the meeting registration and parking.  In total, $85K were used to offer partial support to 98 Kokes Awardees, which included 89 students from more than 50 U.S. universities, 5 students from Canada and 4 students from Mexico. Funds provided by the NSF were used to support over 30 students, all these students were first time Kokes Award winners. Financial support to offset the registration fees and hotel accommodations encouraged greater participation by graduate students. Kokes awardees were required to either deliver an oral or poster presentation, attend the meeting in its entirety and assist the organizing committee in certain meeting operations.  Awardees received a certificate of recognition for being chosen to receive a Richard J. Kokes Award.  The 25th North American Meeting (NAM) had over 1,500 attendees, including 397 students and 97 students Kokes award winners, and 56 exhibitors.  There were 580 oral presentations, 19 keynote presentations, 3 award plenary lectures and ~520 poster presentations.
